articles.headline: Obama to Name Retired General to Top Spy Post
articles.snippet: The prospect of Lt. Gen. James R. Clapper Jr.’s nomination had drawn mixed reactions in Congress.
articles.abstract: The prospect of Lt. Gen. James R. Clapper Jr.’s nomination had drawn mixed reactions in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama has picked Lt. Gen. James R. Clapper Jr. as director of national intelligence, tapping a retired officer with decades of experience to improve coordination of the nation’s sprawling spy apparatus amid increasing threats at home and escalating operations abroad.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Student Debt and a Push for Fairness
articles.snippet: Much of the debt from student loans cannot be erased through bankruptcy, but there’s a movement to change the law.
articles.abstract: Much of the debt from student loans cannot be erased through bankruptcy, but there’s a movement to change the law.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you run up big credit card bills buying a new home theater system and can’t pay it off after a few years, bankruptcy judges can get rid of the debt. They may even erase loans from a casino.

articles.headline: G.M.’s Gift of a Luxury Car Stuns a Few
articles.snippet: Was a prize to a pitcher for a near-perfect game “some of the best dollars invested in publicity,” or a squandering of taxpayers’ equity?
articles.abstract: Was a prize to a pitcher for a near-perfect game “some of the best dollars invested in publicity,” or a squandering of taxpayers’ equity?
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  A free sports car for a Detroit Tigers baseball player was not among the reasons the government saved General Motors from financial collapse. Nor was a year’s supply of diapers and other gifts for a Minnesota woman who gave birth behind the wheel of a Chevrolet Cobalt.

articles.headline: Airlines Work to Catch Up to the Digital Age
articles.snippet: The carriers, recognizing that their antiquated systems contribute to the frustrations of passengers, have begun developing up-to-date technology.
articles.abstract: The carriers, recognizing that their antiquated systems contribute to the frustrations of passengers, have begun developing up-to-date technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airlines have made great technological leaps in recent years, allowing passengers to check in from home or download boarding passes on their smartphones. But if you’ve ever been stranded at an airport during a raging thunderstorm, chances are you will end up standing in a long line watching a gate agent typing furiously on an outdated computer.

articles.headline: Days of Planning Led to Flotilla’s Hour of Chaos
articles.snippet: Weeks of miscalculations set activists on a Turkish boat and Israeli commandos on a collision course.
articles.abstract: Weeks of miscalculations set activists on a Turkish boat and Israeli commandos on a collision course.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — It was just getting light when the Turkish boat, packed with 546 activists, descended into chaos, and Mahmut Coskun, a Turkish doctor on board, was in the middle of it.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Ethan Bronner

articles.headline: A Dubious Way to Prevent Fiscal Crisis
articles.snippet: Will the financial regulation reform bill that emerges from the House and Senate do what it’s intended to do? Probably not.

articles.headline: BP Funneling Some of Leak to the Surface
articles.snippet: In a visit to the Gulf Coast, President Obama kept up his criticism of BP.
articles.abstract: In a visit to the Gulf Coast, President Obama kept up his criticism of BP.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — BP and government officials said Friday that a cap installed over a gushing well in the Gulf of Mexico was funneling some oil and gas to the surface, but they cautioned that much was still leaking and that it would be days before they could declare this latest containment effort a success.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Henry Fountain

articles.headline: For Paul Family, Libertarian Ethos Began at Home
articles.snippet: While Ron Paul’s views produced a family of like-minded thinkers, they inspired Rand to follow his father’s path.
articles.abstract: While Ron Paul’s views produced a family of like-minded thinkers, they inspired Rand to follow his father’s path.

articles.headline: With U.S. Aid, Warlord Builds Afghan Empire
articles.snippet: The most powerful man in Oruzgan Province leads an  army that fights alongside U.S. Special Forces.
articles.abstract: The most powerful man in Oruzgan Province leads an  army that fights alongside U.S. Special Forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIRIN KOT, Afghanistan  The most powerful man in this arid stretch of southern Afghanistan is not the provincial governor, nor the police chief, nor even the commander of the Afghan Army.

articles.headline: We’ll Make You a Star (if the Web Agrees)
articles.snippet: For its shows, Bravo studies its audience’s lifestyle and preferences, and has also begun relying heavily on social media to fine-tune story lines in its programs.
articles.abstract: For its shows, Bravo studies its audience’s lifestyle and preferences, and has also begun relying heavily on social media to fine-tune story lines in its programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE new Bravo reality show “Bethenny Getting Married?” is ready to tape, and its star, an outspoken brunette named Bethenny Frankel, is right on time. She walks into Fig & Olive, an airy Manhattan restaurant, and exchanges cheek kisses with Bravo producers and cameramen. They tell Ms. Frankel, who had a baby just over two weeks earlier, how good she looks.

articles.headline: Debtors’ Prism: Who Has Europe’s Loans?

articles.abstract: Europe is trying to solve a $2.6 trillion mystery — about which banks are holding all that debt from Greece, Spain and Portugal.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT

articles.headline: Banks Say No. Too Bad Taxpayers Can’t.
articles.snippet: Taxpayers could be left holding the bag when institutions try to avoid losses by refusing to buy back problem loans they have sold to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.abstract: Taxpayers could be left holding the bag when institutions try to avoid losses by refusing to buy back problem loans they have sold to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.lead_paragraph: FROM the earliest days of the credit crisis, the nation’s big financial institutions have been less than forthcoming about ballooning loan losses buried inside their books. To some degree this is understandable: denial is a powerful thing, after all, and writing off troubled loans during a period of severe stress is, for bankers, the equivalent of getting a root canal.

articles.headline: In Gulf, It Was Unclear Who Was in Charge of Rig
articles.snippet: A hodgepodge of oversight agencies granted exceptions to rules and  allowed risks to accumulate on the Deepwater Horizon rig.
articles.abstract: A hodgepodge of oversight agencies granted exceptions to rules and  allowed risks to accumulate on the Deepwater Horizon rig.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  Over six days in May, far from the familiar choreography of Washington hearings, federal investigators grilled workers involved in the Deepwater Horizon disaster in a chilly, sterile conference room at a hotel near the airport here.

articles.headline: Hungary Is Playing Political Games on Debt
articles.snippet: Hungary’s new leader is finding it impossible to satisfy both voters and international investors on debt issues.
articles.abstract: Hungary’s new leader is finding it impossible to satisfy both voters and international investors on debt issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the numbers, Hungary is not Greece.

articles.headline: Changing the Course at Newsweek
articles.snippet: It’s easy to throw rocks at an industry dealing with a digital competition and a fractured culture. Here are a few (helpful) ideas.
articles.abstract: It’s easy to throw rocks at an industry dealing with a digital competition and a fractured culture. Here are a few (helpful) ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometime this summer, someone other than The Washington Post will probably own the renowned brand of Newsweek. When I wrote about the pending sale in this column last week, I waxed philosophical about the meaning of a newsweekly magazine in 2010 and prattled on about how ill-conceived Newsweek’s latest redesign was.

articles.headline: Congress Pressed for Reform Bill Deal
articles.snippet: The administration says a deal before President Obama leaves for a G-20 meeting would help persuade other countries to support some of its provisions.
articles.abstract: The administration says a deal before President Obama leaves for a G-20 meeting would help persuade other countries to support some of its provisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As Congressional negotiators begin this week to merge two bills overhauling the financial system, the White House wants them to reach an agreement before President Obama leaves for a Group of 20 meeting this month in Toronto.

articles.headline: Untangling a Ponzi Scheme With a Hollywood Twist
articles.snippet: Kenneth I. Starr is accused in a scheme that has become the talk of celebrities from Hollywood to the Hamptons.
articles.abstract: Kenneth I. Starr is accused in a scheme that has become the talk of celebrities from Hollywood to the Hamptons.
articles.lead_paragraph: Visitors to the Fifth Avenue penthouse were enjoying cocktails, canapés and stunning views of Central Park on a cool May evening as a top New York jeweler laid out his wares for a rarefied group of potential buyers.

articles.headline: App Makers Worry as Data Plans Are Capped
articles.snippet: As AT&T adopts tiered pricing, developers wonder whether consumers will lose their appetite for innovative features and bandwidth-heavy video.
articles.abstract: As AT&T adopts tiered pricing, developers wonder whether consumers will lose their appetite for innovative features and bandwidth-heavy video.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last two years, unlimited data plans have given app-hungry smartphone users an all-you-can-eat buffet. But will customers react to AT&T’s new, limited menu by simply eating less?
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Coast Guard Sees Cleanup of Spill Lasting Until the Fall
articles.snippet: The Coast Guard warned that even if the flow of oil was capped by summer, it could take until autumn to deal with the damage spreading across the gulf.
articles.abstract: The Coast Guard warned that even if the flow of oil was capped by summer, it could take until autumn to deal with the damage spreading across the gulf.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  The Coast Guard commander in charge of the federal response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico warned on Sunday that even if the flow of crude was stopped by summer, it could take well into autumn  and maybe much longer to deal with the slick spreading relentlessly across the gulf.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and John M. Broder

articles.headline: After Suicides, Scrutiny of China’s Grim Factories
articles.snippet: A rash of suicides has intensified scrutiny of the working and living conditions at Foxconn, an electronics supplier.
articles.abstract: A rash of suicides has intensified scrutiny of the working and living conditions at Foxconn, an electronics supplier.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China  The factory’s first death this year came on Jan. 23.

articles.headline: Printing in a Smartphone Age
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard will introduce a fleet of printers with Web access, their own e-mail addresses and touch screens.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard will introduce a fleet of printers with Web access, their own e-mail addresses and touch screens.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO  Vyomesh I. Joshi, the head of Hewlett-Packard’s $24 billion printing empire, relaxes by taking long walks on the beaches near his home here. And, for a while, it seemed as if he might end up spending more time strolling the sand than moving ink and toner.

articles.headline: Convoy Guards in Afghanistan Face an Inquiry
articles.snippet: The security firms are suspected of using U.S. funds to bribe the Taliban and fake attacks to make their services sought after.
articles.abstract: The security firms are suspected of using U.S. funds to bribe the Taliban and fake attacks to make their services sought after.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAIDAN SHAHR, Afghanistan — For months, reports have abounded here that the Afghan mercenaries who escort American and other NATO convoys through the badlands have been bribing Taliban insurgents to let them pass.

articles.headline: Attached to Technology and Paying a Price
articles.snippet: Scientists say our ability to focus is being undermined by bursts of information from e-mail and other interruptions.
articles.abstract: Scientists say our ability to focus is being undermined by bursts of information from e-mail and other interruptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When one of the most important e-mail messages of his life landed in his in-box a few years ago, Kord Campbell overlooked it.

articles.headline: Financial Panel Issues a Subpoena to Goldman Sachs
articles.snippet: Phil Angelides, the chairman of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, said the firm had been uncooperative.
articles.abstract: Phil Angelides, the chairman of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, said the firm had been uncooperative.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The commission investigating the causes of the financial crisis said on Monday that it had subpoenaed Goldman Sachs and harshly accused the investment bank of trying to delay and disrupt its inquiry.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Countrywide Settles Fee Complaint
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission accused the mortgage lender of collecting outsize fees from about 200,000 borrowers facing foreclosure.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission accused the mortgage lender of collecting outsize fees from about 200,000 borrowers facing foreclosure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Countrywide Home Loans and its mortgage servicing unit, which are now part of Bank of America, agreed on Monday to pay $108 million to settle federal charges that the company overcharged customers who were struggling to hang onto their homes.
